release.body: - Context managers (`Specfile.sections()`, `Specfile.tags()` etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - `Specfile.macro_definitions()`), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. `Specfile.version`, `Specfile.license`) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the `with` statement, by using the `content` property (e.g. `Specfile.tags().content`), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use `with` to make changes. (#153)
release.short_description_html: • Context managers (Specfile.sections(), Specfile.tags() etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - Specfile.macro_definitions()), and it is also possible to use tag propert…

pull_request.title: Release 0.11.0
pull_request.body: Update the changelog and the specfile for release 0.11.0.

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

commits.message:
Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top
of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers
a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same
as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally
use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix
and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example
macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite
each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.

Signed-off-by: Nikola Forró <nforro@redhat.com>

Merge pull request #153 from packit/context_management

Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.
Now it is also possible to access data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using GeneratorContextManager.content property (I'm open to suggestions how to name it better):
for tag in spec.tags().content:
    print(f"{tag.name}: {tag.expanded_value}")
No modifications will be preserved though.

RELEASE NOTES BEGIN
Context managers (Specfile.sections(), Specfile.tags() etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - Specfile.macro_definitions()), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. Specfile.version, Specfile.license) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using the content property (e.g. Specfile.tags().content), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use with to make changes.
RELEASE NOTES END

Reviewed-by: František Nečas <frantisek.necas@protonmail.com>
Reviewed-by: Nikola Forró <None>

release.body:
- Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)
- Packit now resets the `Release` tag during `propose-downstream` if the version is updated and the `Release` tag has not explicitly been overridden in the upstream specfile. (#1801)
release.short_description_html:
• Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)

release.body: - Context managers (`Specfile.sections()`, `Specfile.tags()` etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - `Specfile.macro_definitions()`), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. `Specfile.version`, `Specfile.license`) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the `with` statement, by using the `content` property (e.g. `Specfile.tags().content`), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use `with` to make changes. (#153)
release.short_description_html: • Context managers (Specfile.sections(), Specfile.tags() etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - Specfile.macro_definitions()), and it is also possible to use tag propert…

pull_request.title: Release 0.11.0
pull_request.body: Update the changelog and the specfile for release 0.11.0.

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

commits.message:
Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top
of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers
a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same
as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally
use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix
and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example
macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite
each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.

Signed-off-by: Nikola Forró <nforro@redhat.com>

Merge pull request #153 from packit/context_management

Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.
Now it is also possible to access data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using GeneratorContextManager.content property (I'm open to suggestions how to name it better):
for tag in spec.tags().content:
    print(f"{tag.name}: {tag.expanded_value}")
No modifications will be preserved though.

RELEASE NOTES BEGIN
Context managers (Specfile.sections(), Specfile.tags() etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - Specfile.macro_definitions()), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. Specfile.version, Specfile.license) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using the content property (e.g. Specfile.tags().content), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use with to make changes.
RELEASE NOTES END

Reviewed-by: František Nečas <frantisek.necas@protonmail.com>
Reviewed-by: Nikola Forró <None>

release.body:
- Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)
- Packit now resets the `Release` tag during `propose-downstream` if the version is updated and the `Release` tag has not explicitly been overridden in the upstream specfile. (#1801)
release.short_description_html:
• Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)

release.body: - Context managers (`Specfile.sections()`, `Specfile.tags()` etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - `Specfile.macro_definitions()`), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. `Specfile.version`, `Specfile.license`) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the `with` statement, by using the `content` property (e.g. `Specfile.tags().content`), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use `with` to make changes. (#153)

pull_request.title: Release 0.11.0
pull_request.body: Update the changelog and the specfile for release 0.11.0.

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

repo.name: specfile
repo.description: A library for parsing and manipulating RPM spec files

commits.message:
Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top
of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers
a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same
as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally
use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix
and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example
macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite
each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.

Signed-off-by: Nikola Forró <nforro@redhat.com>

Merge pull request #153 from packit/context_management

Make context managers better

This commit introduces a new ContextManager decorator that builds on top of contextlib.contextmanager and effectively makes context managers a singleton. Any nested context of the same kind will be the same as the outermost context of that particular kind.
This makes it possible, for example, to set properties that internally use context managers inside an existing context, or in general mix and nest context managers almost freely.
There are still instances of conflicting context managers, for example macro_definitions() and sections(), that, when combined, will overwrite each other's underlying data. All such instances will be documented.
Now it is also possible to access data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using GeneratorContextManager.content property (I'm open to suggestions how to name it better):
for tag in spec.tags().content:
    print(f"{tag.name}: {tag.expanded_value}")
No modifications will be preserved though.

RELEASE NOTES BEGIN
Context managers (Specfile.sections(), Specfile.tags() etc.) can now be nested and combined together (with one exception - Specfile.macro_definitions()), and it is also possible to use tag properties (e.g. Specfile.version, Specfile.license) inside them. It is also possible to access the data directly, avoiding the with statement, by using the content property (e.g. Specfile.tags().content), but be aware that no modifications done to such data will be preserved. You must use with to make changes.
RELEASE NOTES END

Reviewed-by: František Nečas <frantisek.necas@protonmail.com>
Reviewed-by: Nikola Forró <None>

release.body:
- Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)
- Packit now resets the `Release` tag during `propose-downstream` if the version is updated and the `Release` tag has not explicitly been overridden in the upstream specfile. (#1801)
release.short_description_html:
• Packit now correctly handles a race condition when it tries to create bodhi updates for builds that are not yet tagged properly. CLI exprience was also improved for this case. (#1803)
